snippet: Shootings by preschoolers are happening at an average pace of about two per week. A child who accidentally pulls the trigger is most likely to be 3 years old.
abstract: Four toddlers across country accidentally fatally shoot themselves over one week in April 2016; incidents, in which children died after finding and handling firearms owned by their family members, recounted; prosecutors wrestle with holding grieving parents criminally responsible, while gun rights advocates say such tragedies are too rare to justify change in gun laws.

byline.original: By JACK HEALY, JULIE BOSMAN, ALAN BLINDER and JULIE TURKEWITZ
byline.contributor: Jack Healy reported from Kansas City; Julie Bosman from Chicago; Alan Blinder from Dallas, Ga.; and Julie Turkewitz from Denver. Mitch Smith contributed reporting from Chicago; Ian Lovett from Wilseyville, Calif.; Jack Begg from New York; and Nathan Magner from Bermuda, La.

lead_paragraph: Shootings by preschoolers are happening at an average pace of about two per week. A child who accidentally pulls the trigger is most likely to be 3 years old.

headline.main: One Week in April, Four Toddlers Shot and Killed Themselves
headline.print_headline: Guns in Tiny Hands: In a Week, Four Toddlers Shoot Themselves
